[h3] Conclusion [/h3]
Horizon Walker is very friendly compared to other gacha games on the casual aspect, and this applies to their gacha system. The gacha can be used by two currency, the rare one done by slowly playing the game and the common gold currency used for everything. This makes obtaining enough pulls for a character really easy, while you can also get free tickets for pulls too. The character banners and weapons are guaranteed, no gamble on getting something you don't want just gambling against pity, which is like 40 pulls if you win at the casino kind of odds but the other direction. They also put the characters into the standard banner with their weapon, so everything just gets lumped into one banner eventually. Best odds getting what you want is waiting for the reruns so you aren't fighting against other characters and weapons.

The casual grind is extremely easy, since this game is made to be an auto battle mobile game. You can auto battle your daily quests in a few minutes and that is all, but you should be progressing as much as you can since it effects the rewards you farm. Which is also easy if you have the right team that you can leave on auto, some teams will need you to play manually. Later on when you reach towards the end goal you will naturally come to a crawl and halt, but there isn't a need to push yourself since this game has zero online aspect, you will not interact with other players in any way not even a friend system exists kind of nothing.

Character balance is not bad at all, but also not great. Their aren't too many useless characters, but there are a few that are so broken it would be foolish not to use them. So you go from using whatever to using the same team for everything because they break everything. There are only some cases that you should pick the right team for the right situation, but for the most part just use the broken characters on auto. Which is a shame considering every character gets a skin, so there will be people who want to use their favorites over meta if they can.

Skins are well... A treat to say the least, most of them are fan service and very few are just cute. They do hand out free skins on special occasions, but for the most part they are obtained by paying/grinding really hard. This game also does really well with FOMO, skins that are in the battlepass or events will eventually cycle into the shop for you to get for free if you have the currency. These skins are present in the story, so you will see the skins you have equipped for each character when watching the story, which you could argue adds a bit more value to the skin knowing they are used everywhere not just gameplay.

Fan service is well one of the stronger points of the game, the story uses it heavily and can be funny at times with small jokes nothing to give an award for. Skins and interactions all aim towards that goal as well. What sets Horizon Walker's fan service apart from other games, is that you can interact with the characters more deeply (in both ways). You get to pretend text and use social media with the characters, to doing stuff. Each character has an affection level, and once you reach level 5 the max, well let's just say you shouldn't open that in public. Its essentially almost full nudity with the exception to the crotch for laws in the game's native region. That is the extent they go, no actual action happens you just get to admire anatomy.

Story is well... What you would expect for one focused on fan service, nothing that would capture you in it nor is it incoherent you can't try it even if you wanted to. If story carries a lot of weight in your enjoyment instead of minimal thinking auto press kind of game, then you will most likely find it hard to enjoy especially if you aren't a fan of shallow fan service. Think of trashy harem anime with that kind of comedy and a minimal character lead.

[h3] TLDR [/h3]
It is an auto battle mobile game, which really nice systems in place to make it fun and casual with tons of fan service. Story isn't too interesting, but can be funny with the characters interacting with each other. True enjoyment is minimal thinking, look at hot anime women say and do things, which you get to dress up if you spend money or grind for it. Almost no FOMO in this gacha game if you can wait about 1-2 months for stuff to comeback for potentially free if you play enough, banners take longer since each one lasts a long time. Difficulty = reeeaaallly casual, Casual grind = easy, Gacha = get everything if you play enough, Skins = all free if you play enough/wait, Fan service = peak, Gameplay = auto mode, Everything = free if you play a bit.

[h1]The Short Review[/h1]
It's fine despite a lot of gripes. You'll get what you want out of the game for free and nothing is inherently wrong with the gameplay loop, but your mileage varies based on your tolerance for monotony.

[h2]The Long Review[/h2]
Horizon Walker is probably everything you've heard from word of mouth and other reviews: a generous, f2p friendly gacha game, a surprisingly deep strategy game, a treasure trove of mature booba...
It is also a game I don't take too much issue with, but at the same time don't feel like playing much anymore. Hopefully I can explain why.

[b][u]The Pros[/u][/b]
[b]Gameplay:[/b] The strategy gameplay loop is strong for something in the gacha space. Usually these games let you roll the newest SSR character and just autoplay through all the content. Horizon Walker relies more on team cooperation and combos to keep you interested in the combat. Sure it has an auto mode but unless you're vastly overstatted it's not a free win.

[b]Generosity:[/b] Horizon Walker's gacha system is rather unique. You roll for vanguards using a ticket resource and recruit them by paying in-game currency or items. Paid currency is only a fall-back option (of course a f2p game is going to have a pay4everything option). Thanks to in-game events it's very easy to hit the 10-roll pity on any vanguard you could ever want. Additionally the story throws a plethora of vanguards at you for free, some of which are quality choices in endgame teams.

[b]Cheesecake:[/b] This is the full disclosure on the content everyone wants to here about - this game features topless women, clothing that barely qualifies as such, and implied sex with your max affection vanguards. It's rare for a gacha available in english to offer anything outside of baiting and cheap live2D, so when you hear this game has fans you will see why pretty quickly.

[b][u]The Cons[/u][/b]
[b]Implementation:[/b] This is a minor one and I'm really only putting this for disclosure. This is a mobile game port handled by a small localization team. Additionally it uses an anti-cheat despite the lack of multiplayer features. Take these for what you will.

[b]Story:[/b] Your eyes may glaze over depending on your tolerance for Korean webcomic schlock. So you died (maybe) and devoured a dark god, becoming a living god that all the women love. And you must help the vanguards to stop Cronenberg monsters emerging from hell portals into a post-apocalyptic world. Also there are portals to an isekai dimension that some of your waifus come from? Don't think about it too hard because the writers sure don't. Plot threads are only developed far enough to establish the next plot thread to chase with no sense of over-arching narrative or conflict to act as a throughline. Probably a smyptom of the typical gacha tactic of write-as-you-go "infinite story" design.

[b]Systems Gating:[/b] As with any live service Horizon Walker is absolutely inundated with overlapping systems and they all restrict the player in different ways. You have to manually level your vanguards with materials, but only as high as your Human God(the MC)'s level. The Human God levels up with experience from missions or tribute (a passive income based on real time that increases based on story progress). You can level up weapons without such a cap, but every ten levels you need to use a different material that is available based on story progress. Stigmas (equipment) have level caps based on rarity, and rarity is another thing gated by story progress. And if you guessed all three of these things had different materials spent to level up, you'd be right!

[b]Affection:[/b] If you want to get to the good stuff (aka the booba) you need to learn how to raise affection with your vanguards. This is most directly done through the gifting of affection items. As far as my 33 hours into the game can testify these are gained through daily rewards and events. Meaning that if you only care about specific girls and not minmaxing the gameplay there is no meaningful recourse to grind out affection through playing. This was one of my deciding factors for uninstalling alongside...

[b]Monotony:[/b] Story is not this game's strong suit. Neither is game balance. Getting a decent team comp built around the right EX vanguard with high AoE damage will let you breeze through battles utilizing the same combo every time. And therein lies the problem. Enemy comps and strategies are never varied enough to challenge your winning strategy or require you to adjust at all, making battle very samey (outside of content that explicitly locks you out of units) and content a slog to get through. This might be where autobattling would come in but unfortunately the combo/systems-heavy gameplay works against itself here, with the AI unable to properly use most vanguards and only help in pure stat check situtations.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
So why am I recommending a game I spent so many words slagging off? Because overall the time I spent with Horizon Walker was entertaining. It was fun. The problem is that it was not engaging; not addictive. In an industry rife with live service games vying for your time games like these are either hard to put down... or they are put down. Enjoy it for a while. How long that while is will vary but it won't be time wasted.

Hot Girls, Fun mechanics, Easy to understand, and you earn pull currency while AFK... Is it buggy at times? Yeah, but nothing too gamebreaking. The most ecchi and F2P gacha I've ever seen, and I'm not someone who recommends Gacha games.

Ignore my hours in the Steam version, I've got easily 30 times more in the mobile version. Amazing character design, solid gameplay, and one of, if not the best, gacha games I have ever played when it comes to monetization and F2P friendliness, Horizon Walker is great for anyone interested in giving it a try.

First off, this is indeed a gooner game, but it's all pretty softcore, there's character affection which is raised by different methods (all free of course) and that leads to massage, hot tub, or pillow talk scenes in the nude but no actual doing of the dirty deed. That being said, the outfits and character design are incredibly eye catching. 

The gameplay itself is turn based combat, think something like a more simplified version of Baldur's Gate or Divinity. It's not anything ground breaking but it's done well and satisfying. Each character has an archetype of tank, support, or DPS which are broken into further subclasses. Leveling the characters is pretty simple, just using mats from dailies or story missions, but building them can get more in depth, with different equipments and give various stat boosts and set bonuses, making for some pretty crazy turn one clear comps. Every character is easily obtainable for free once you get to a certain point in the game, and at no point do you feel pressured to spend to progress the regular story. Which brings me to the monetization. 

Unlike other gacha games, Horizon Walker uses the regular in game currency of gold, which is earned from just about everything, to let you pull for characters. 4 pulls guarantees an SS, and 10 an EX. Character repeats do offer advantages but you can use dupes of any character to level any other character. There's still a premium currency you can use in place of gold but it's optional and mainly used for buying cosmetics, or whaling if you like. 

Added note, if you start on the Steam version, or already play the mobile version, you can link the accounts to one another.

You characters arrive in a specific location on the combat map with the camera casting a top down view of the combat area. You then spend ACTION POINTS to chose how far your character moves, and after your movement you determine if you character will stay put or activate an ability. Your ability range from attacks, to healing, buff or debuffs, Attacks/Actions can be
A. focused one a single target and only hit that target
B. focused on single target but hit multiple targets
C. non-focused attacks that hit in a chosen direction or area
D. require multiple turns to fully charge before being cast
E. activate passively under varying conditions. {incoming attacks, out going attack, Etc}

The most noteable thing about the combat is the inclusion of critical strikes and the possibility of "back-attacks" that promise a criticle strike which avoids enemy defense and can boost your dmg output. Taking advantage of back-attacks may not only increase your chances of victory in some fights... but may greatly reduce the amount of turns require to complete a mission as well. There is an auto combat button in case you believe you characters might be powerful enough to just Unga bunga smash their way through a fight... but the COMABT A.I. [h3] Conclusion [/h3]
Horizon Walker is very friendly compared to other gacha games on the casual aspect, and this applies to their gacha system. The gacha can be used by two currency, the rare one done by slowly playing the game and the common gold currency used for everything. This makes obtaining enough pulls for a character really easy, while you can also get free tickets for pulls too. The character banners and weapons are guaranteed, no gamble on getting something you don't want just gambling against pity, which is like 40 pulls if you win at the casino kind of odds but the other direction. They also put the characters into the standard banner with their weapon, so everything just gets lumped into one banner eventually. Best odds getting what you want is waiting for the reruns so you aren't fighting against other characters and weapons.

The casual grind is extremely easy, since this game is made to be an auto battle mobile game. You can auto battle your daily quests in a few minutes and that is all, but you should be progressing as much as you can since it effects the rewards you farm. Which is also easy if you have the right team that you can leave on auto, some teams will need you to play manually. Later on when you reach towards the end goal you will naturally come to a crawl and halt, but there isn't a need to push yourself since this game has zero online aspect, you will not interact with other players in any way not even a friend system exists kind of nothing.

Character balance is not bad at all, but also not great. Their aren't too many useless characters, but there are a few that are so broken it would be foolish not to use them. So you go from using whatever to using the same team for everything because they break everything. There are only some cases that you should pick the right team for the right situation, but for the most part just use the broken characters on auto. Which is a shame considering every character gets a skin, so there will be people who want to use their favorites over meta if they can.

Skins are well... A treat to say the least, most of them are fan service and very few are just cute. They do hand out free skins on special occasions, but for the most part they are obtained by paying/grinding really hard. This game also does really well with FOMO, skins that are in the battlepass or events will eventually cycle into the shop for you to get for free if you have the currency. These skins are present in the story, so you will see the skins you have equipped for each character when watching the story, which you could argue adds a bit more value to the skin knowing they are used everywhere not just gameplay.

Fan service is well one of the stronger points of the game, the story uses it heavily and can be funny at times with small jokes nothing to give an award for. Skins and interactions all aim towards that goal as well. What sets Horizon Walker's fan service apart from other games, is that you can interact with the characters more deeply (in both ways). You get to pretend text and use social media with the characters, to doing stuff. Each character has an affection level, and once you reach level 5 the max, well let's just say you shouldn't open that in public. Its essentially almost full nudity with the exception to the crotch for laws in the game's native region. That is the extent they go, no actual action happens you just get to admire anatomy.

Story is well... What you would expect for one focused on fan service, nothing that would capture you in it nor is it incoherent you can't try it even if you wanted to. If story carries a lot of weight in your enjoyment instead of minimal thinking auto press kind of game, then you will most likely find it hard to enjoy especially if you aren't a fan of shallow fan service. Think of trashy harem anime with that kind of comedy and a minimal character lead.

[h3] TLDR [/h3]
It is an auto battle mobile game, which really nice systems in place to make it fun and casual with tons of fan service. Story isn't too interesting, but can be funny with the characters interacting with each other. True enjoyment is minimal thinking, look at hot anime women say and do things, which you get to dress up if you spend money or grind for it. Almost no FOMO in this gacha game if you can wait about 1-2 months for stuff to comeback for potentially free if you play enough, banners take longer since each one lasts a long time. Difficulty = reeeaaallly casual, Casual grind = easy, Gacha = get everything if you play enough, Skins = all free if you play enough/wait, Fan service = peak, Gameplay = auto mode, Everything = free if you play a bit.

I don't recommend this game. Not because of the absurd privacy policy or the rightfully criticized kernel level anti-cheat, but because it fails to deliver what I hoped for from a harem game.

Don't get me wrong; the characters are visually stunning and the gameplay is serviceable, but all of that is meaningless when we're forced to play as a useless mouth-breather of a MC who just stands around while the other characters do and solve everything.

The story flow goes as follows: There's a problem that needs to be solved, usually in the form of an enemy group, so our characters go there and talk among themselves about the best course of action. Yeon Chaeyoung is the mediator/leader in 99% of all conversations while the Human God (you) just watches and occasionally chimes in with a "Mhm." Then the characters talk for a bit longer before turning to you and saying "Give the order, Human God," to which you reply with "Let's do this."

If you can't see why I have a problem with that, let me put it this way. I can count on one hand the amount of times the Human God was [b]alone[/b] with another girl. And even when he was, someone quickly arrives to do all the talking for him. It genuinely feels like you're playing as a small toddler who needs his mom to drive every conversation for him. The result is a very passive and uninteresting protagonist who never [b]earns[/b] the girls' affection or goes out of his way to help them. Even in the individual character stories (private chats and VN-style sequences), there's always a group chat with three other girls doing all the talking and solving the problems of the girl you're "bonding" with. I have nothing against group interactions, but when the protagonist feels like a cardboard cutout with zero presence or leadership, it feels less like a harem game and more like an all-girls cast occasionally glancing at an empty husk meant to represent the player. I kid you not, there are many scenes where the girls literally say "Oh, Human God, you were there the whole time?" or "Oh, we didn't see you there, Human God."

I was putting off writing this review because I genuinely hoped not all character stories were like this. But what broke the camel's back was Everette's story. Without spoilers, what I can say is that the Human God vowed to help her solve a very serious problem of hers, only to let a literal child take the lead and summon a divine being, then proceeding to tell HER to talk to the divine being in his stead. And when they finally get what they wanted, the Human God can't even be bothered to hand the thing to Everette himself. He tells the little girl to do it, because for some reason this game is afraid of showing any scene where the MC takes the lead at any point.

Sure, there are the massage/bath/bed scenes where we can touch and talk to the girls one-on-one, but that's completely isolated from the story and 100% optional. It's just there to showcase the admittedly beautiful models and impressive physics, but it doesn't change the fact that we didn't [b]earn[/b] this. We just nodded and grunted our way into the girl's heart. Here's an assortment of the MC's greatest hits: "Mhm" "..." "Yep." "k" "??" "...!" "Let's go"

And look, even though I focused on the MC's complete lack of presence and authority in this review, that doesn't mean it's the only problem in this game. The story itself is... empty. I know it's still at a very early stage, but I reached the end of all available content and I'm left genuinely confused as to what we're even doing. There's no goal or even a faint idea of what to do next, just the protagonist being led around by his unearned harem while doing odd jobs. As for the character stories, some are good and spicy (Lisandria, Cora), but most are incredibly forgettable (Olivia, Vlissing, Fammene) or even offensively bad and half-baked (Korabi). For a harem game that prides itself on the shameless fanservice, the actual [b]bonding[/b] experience is embarrassingly bad. Pretty much every other waifu collector I've ever played had more care put into the characters' stories. Horizon Walker, on the other hand, feels disjointed and empty in comparison.

Of course, not all is bad. This is a very generous and F2P-friendly game. So if you're just here for the beautiful character models and blatant fanservice, go right ahead. I'm pretty sure you can get at least one copy of every character as a F2P player, as the monetization is focused on the skins. And save for a few exceptions, dupes aren't very important. But do be warned that the game has weapon gacha. Normally I wouldn't even touch a game with weapon gacha, but there's no 50/50 here, so you're guaranteed to get the banner character/weapon within 50 pulls. With that being said, the lack of regional pricing makes a lot of things ridiculously expensive if you happen to live in the wrong part of the world. I really wish they'd change that, but unfortunately I don't see it happening.

The gameplay is fine, but I do have many gripes with it. The game features aggro adjustment, but most bosses and even regular enemies are designed to ignore aggro. The AI will casually walk out of melee range from one of your characters before nuking your back line, and there's nothing you can do but brute-force your way through with upgrades or a reduced formation, This means that there's no real sense of strategy in this game, just turn manipulation and raw stats. Some enemies are very frustrating to deal with unless you have a specific unit, so in that sense, the game does feel a bit "pay-to-progress" when it really shouldn't have to be that way.

As a final note, this review could very well change to a positive one if they simply start putting more care into the character stories and how the protagonist interacts with his harem. They really took the "Blank Slate MC" trope to the extreme, and it's unacceptable how little presence we have in the girls' lives. I don't know if it's because they're afraid of breaking the self-insert fantasy or what, but I've played countless self-insert games where no one complained about the protagonist having more agency and authority. I say this because it's clear that they [b]know[/b] how to write an assertive MC (as seen on Lisandria's bond story), but they intentionally choose not to.

I don't recommend this game. Not because of the absurd privacy policy or the rightfully criticized kernel level anti-cheat, but because it fails to deliver what I hoped for from a harem game.

Don't get me wrong; the characters are visually stunning and the gameplay is serviceable, but all of that is meaningless when we're forced to play as a useless mouth-breather of a MC who just stands around while the other characters do and solve everything.

The story flow goes as follows: There's a problem that needs to be solved, usually in the form of an enemy group, so our characters go there and talk among themselves about the best course of action. Yeon Chaeyoung is the mediator/leader in 99% of all conversations while the Human God (you) just watches and occasionally chimes in with a "Mhm." Then the characters talk for a bit longer before turning to you and saying "Give the order, Human God," to which you reply with "Let's do this."

If you can't see why I have a problem with that, let me put it this way. I can count on one hand the amount of times the Human God was [b]alone[/b] with another girl. And even when he was, someone quickly arrives to do all the talking for him. It genuinely feels like you're playing as a small toddler who needs his mom to drive every conversation for him. The result is a very passive and uninteresting protagonist who never [b]earns[/b] the girls' affection or goes out of his way to help them. Even in the individual character stories (private chats and VN-style sequences), there's always a group chat with three other girls doing all the talking and solving the problems of the girl you're "bonding" with. I have nothing against group interactions, but when the protagonist feels like a cardboard cutout with zero presence or leadership, it feels less like a harem game and more like an all-girls cast occasionally glancing at an empty husk meant to represent the player. I kid you not, there are many scenes where the girls literally say "Oh, Human God, you were there the whole time?" or "Oh, we didn't see you there, Human God."

I was putting off writing this review because I genuinely hoped not all character stories were like this. But what broke the camel's back was Everette's story. Without spoilers, what I can say is that the Human God vowed to help her solve a very serious problem of hers, only to let a literal child take the lead and summon a divine being, then proceeding to tell HER to talk to the divine being in his stead. And when they finally get what they wanted, the Human God can't even be bothered to hand the thing to Everette himself. He tells the little girl to do it, because for some reason this game is afraid of showing any scene where the MC takes the lead at any point.

Sure, there are the massage/bath/bed scenes where we can touch and talk to the girls one-on-one, but that's completely isolated from the story and 100% optional. It's just there to showcase the admittedly beautiful models and impressive physics, but it doesn't change the fact that we didn't [b]earn[/b] this. We just nodded and grunted our way into the girl's heart. Here's an assortment of the MC's greatest hits: "Mhm" "..." "Yep." "k" "??" "...!" "Let's go"

And look, even though I focused on the MC's complete lack of presence and authority in this review, that doesn't mean it's the only problem in this game. The story itself is... empty. I know it's still at a very early stage, but I reached the end of all available content and I'm left genuinely confused as to what we're even doing. There's no goal or even a faint idea of what to do next, just the protagonist being led around by his unearned harem while doing odd jobs. As for the character stories, some are good and spicy (Lisandria, Cora), but most are incredibly forgettable (Olivia, Vlissing, Fammene) or even offensively bad and half-baked (Korabi). For a harem game that prides itself on the shameless fanservice, the actual [b]bonding[/b] experience is embarrassingly bad. Pretty much every other waifu collector I've ever played had more care put into the characters' stories. Horizon Walker, on the other hand, feels disjointed and empty in comparison.

Of course, not all is bad. This is a very generous and F2P-friendly game. So if you're just here for the beautiful character models and blatant fanservice, go right ahead. I'm pretty sure you can get at least one copy of every character as a F2P player, as the monetization is focused on the skins. And save for a few exceptions, dupes aren't very important. But do be warned that the game has weapon gacha. Normally I wouldn't even touch a game with weapon gacha, but there's no 50/50 here, so you're guaranteed to get the banner character/weapon within 50 pulls. With that being said, the lack of regional pricing makes a lot of things ridiculously expensive if you happen to live in the wrong part of the world. I really wish they'd change that, but unfortunately I don't see it happening.

The gameplay is fine, but I do have many gripes with it. The game features aggro adjustment, but most bosses and even regular enemies are designed to ignore aggro. The AI will casually walk out of melee range from one of your characters before nuking your back line, and there's nothing you can do but brute-force your way through with upgrades or a reduced formation, This means that there's no real sense of strategy in this game, just turn manipulation and raw stats. Some enemies are very frustrating to deal with unless you have a specific unit, so in that sense, the game does feel a bit "pay-to-progress" when it really shouldn't have to be that way.

As a final note, this review could very well change to a positive one if they simply start putting more care into the character stories and how the protagonist interacts with his harem. They really took the "Blank Slate MC" trope to the extreme, and it's unacceptable how little presence we have in the girls' lives. I don't know if it's because they're afraid of breaking the self-insert fantasy or what, but I've played countless self-insert games where no one complained about the protagonist having more agency and authority. I say this because it's clear that they [b]know[/b] how to write an assertive MC (as seen on Lisandria's bond story), but they intentionally choose not to.

First of all, the technical perfomance of this thing is horrible. The cutscenes skip frames and stutter so much that the audio straight up desyncs from the video. It also updates constantly, and overall the game doesn't even look all that good (it looks like a PS3/360 title), so I have no idea why it's perfomance is so bad. And the game couldn't even be launched for the first couple of days of its release, which is abysmal for a game that 1) isn't even an early-access title 2) had launched previously on other platforms in Asia, so they should've had the time to iron the kinks out. 

Next, the game has a sort of cool premise, but the execution is the definition of 'generic'. It's just a very basic harem anime. You play as some god dude who is protecting the remnants of manking from some sort of monsters in a post apocalyptic future. The game tells us at the beginning that things are very bad, there is only one human city remaining, and the monsters are close to winning. Don't worry though, none of this will ever impact your actual game experience. You are going to spend plenty of time on dumb dormroom-esque shenanigans with a bunch of big-titty anime women. You can go on dates, go get a message. Everyone is always clean and well-dressed, there doesn't seem to be any shortage of food, water, electricity. This whole "incoming exctintion of mankind" thing is actually no big deal. We can relax.

From the promos I thought that this was going to be like an Xcom style strategy combat game. It's not that. It's just a JRPG with a typical combat for the genre. You have a team of fighters, each one with a set of abilities, and you use those abilities to fight monsters in turn-based battles. Thinking is not really required here. Your team is almost always very overpowedered and crushes the enemies with ease. Once I decided to check my socials on my phone while I was waiting for the enemies to do their turn. And then suddenly I saw that we won that battle. Your heroes have an ability to atuomatically counter-attack when the enemy is close enough, so they just killed all the enemies without me. My input wasn't even necessary.

The game is also a very shoddy port from mobile phones. Even here on PC you control the game as if you have a touch screen, but you use your mouse instead of your real-world fingers. It's as if they forgot that keyboard exists, or maybe they just didn't care at all.

Finally, let's talk about the main reason most people play this: the gooning material. The oversexualization in this game is ridiculous. Every female character has gigantic milkers with jiggle physics cranked up to 11. I think a few of these characters should be able to accidentally punch themselves in the face with their own breasts if they were to make a sudden wrong move.
I am not sure if this is supposed to be genuinely titilating for someone, or is this a self-parody of how videogames often handle fanservice. It doesn't really work either way, honestly. 
Look, I get the gooner logic. I am not above this stuff. But I feel like this game has no variety of character designs for gooning purposes. There's only 2 body types for women here: attractive woman with big breats, and an attractive woman with giant breasts. I love me some titties, but when every single character has them exposed, and they shake in every direction at the slightest provocation, then I quickly lose all interest in them titties. 
Let me explain this with a food metaphor: I do love me some mac'n'cheese, it's probably my favorite food. But if I had to make it my entire diet, I'd loathe even the idea of another mac'n'cheese after just a week of eating nothing but that.
Same with big honkers. They're great, but if everyone has them, it's like what even are big honkers anymore?

In short, don't play this game. Yeah, it's free, but it's not worth it even for this price. In general you should play real, good games instead of this Gacha gooner-bait, but even if you are into this sort of stuff, there are so many other better Gacha gooner games out there that are also free.
